node.title: Reactor meshing workshop May 16
node.bodyText:
Hello
A MOOSE Reactor Module Training will be held virtually next month on Tuesday, May 16 (10AM - 5PM ET).
It is free, but registration is required.
Registration deadline for U.S. citizens is May 9 at 5:00pm CT.
Registration deadline for foreign nationals is April 25 at 5:00pm CT.
Topics: Meshing workflow, extra element IDs, common mesh generators & examples, how to use with Griffin, the Reactor Geometry Mesh Builder routines and examples, and advanced meshing tool intro
Register online here.
Best,
Guillaume for the Reactor Module team

Hi Guillaume ! @GiudGiud
I registered for it using the link but I did not get any confirmation email (I actually tried it two times !). Will the meeting details be shared only close to the workshop ?
-Kamal
@eshemon
@KamalnathOSU Hi there, yes, sorry about that. We will share the meeting agenda and link a week before the workshop! It will be 10-5:30ET May 16.
Is their a mailing list we can register, would like to receive notification of such future event, missed it this time.

Hello
We've transitioned to using Github discussions for newsletters & announcements.
This might be a little too high volume.
We'll talk about reviving the mailing list and let you know
Guillaume
Is there a remote chance to still register or access link to recording?

Hello
Are you reading this in serial?
Did you ever get it to completion?
Do you have the option to convert it to another supported mesh format?
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/meshgenerators/FileMeshGenerator.html
Guillaume

Hi Guillaume,
I am using mpi in sending this job. But I am not sure whether the MOOSE is reading it in parallel. Because you are right, I find I can hardly make it completed.
I think it can be saved in another format. But I am not sure which one can be optimal.
Reed
Have you had it read in serial once?
if you have, you can save it to exodus from MOOSE. Reading exodus should pose no issue at all and be quite fast

I believe I knew what happened. I just tried to run it in serial and I found it looks like I requested just so limited memory in reading this mesh file. But for some reason, the console still shows it was dealing with the mesh. Maybe there is something that can be improved here.
Thanks for the help!

node.title: Field split for scalar variables
node.bodyText:
Regarding the field split preconditioner:
I noticed in Split.C that there is a guard against scalar variables:
if (!_fe_problem.hasVariable(var))
However, lower in the code (PetscDMMoose.C) it actually does allow for scalar variables. When I commented the line above and ran a test case combining a regular and scalar variable with field splitting, the iterative solvers ran fine.
Is this guard intentional or an oversight? If nothing else prevents changing it to
if (!_fe_problem.hasVariable(var) && !_fe_problem.hasScalarVariable(var))
then I can do that, add a test input file, and also fix a typo I had in one of my doc files in a previous pull request.

Hello
Which syntax are you using for the field split? There's two
I think it got enabled recently for the [Preconditioning] type=FSP syntax, that may be why it s disallowed in your case.
Guillaume

I am using the [Preconditioning]  active = 'FSP' syntax, not the one that Contact Split is based off of. However, I'm using the source code from 4/7/2023. But when I look in the current github source, the Split.C file looks the same. I can try the [Splits] syntax, but when I skim the source it looks like both syntaxes will pass through that same source file.
Let me know if you want me to attach the input file.
I would open a PR with a test case so we can review. Sounds like a possible oversight

node.title: Dynamics of an object
node.bodyText: Is there an example code that models the the Newtonian motion of an object where there can be an initial condition that accelerates the object, and the following trajectory of the object is influenced by gravity and the initial condition?
@jiangwen84 @recuero
@Strawberrybrother answer might matter to you too

I cannot find such an example now. But I have played with a similar setup using the Newmark integrator. You can using gravity and initial conditions on the variables (including auxiliary velocity and acceleration) to achieve what you describe. Note that you shouldn't use mass damping if you want to get physical results, as it will damp out rigid body motion.

node.title: Issue using cuda and openmpi
node.bodyText:
Hi all,
I have the following issue when trying to execute a simulation file on a gpu hpc cluster.
The following error.
._____________________________________________________________________________________
|
| Initial checks...
| All good.
|_____________________________________________________________________________________
[gpu008:162305] OPAL ERROR: Not initialized in file pmix3x_client.c at line 112
--------------------------------------------------------------------------
The application appears to have been direct launched using "srun",
but OMPI was not built with SLURM's PMI support and therefore cannot
execute. There are several options for building PMI support under
SLURM, depending upon the SLURM version you are using:

  version 16.05 or later: you can use SLURM's PMIx support. This
  requires that you configure and build SLURM --with-pmix.

  Versions earlier than 16.05: you must use either SLURM's PMI-1 or
  PMI-2 support. SLURM builds PMI-1 by default, or you can manually
  install PMI-2. You must then build Open MPI using --with-pmi pointing
  to the SLURM PMI library location.

Please configure as appropriate and try again.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------
*** An error occurred in MPI_Init
*** on a NULL communicator
*** MPI_ERRORS_ARE_FATAL (processes in this communicator will now abort,
***    and potentially your MPI job)
[gpu008:162305] Local abort before MPI_INIT completed completed successfully, but am not able to aggregate error messages, and not able to guarantee that all other processes were killed!

previously i was using the loaded module of openmpi4.1.1, but after finding that one existed in /usr/mpi/gcc/openmpi4.0.1a1, i editted the $Path and $ldlibrarypath based on the outputs of ldd , but am still getting the same error.
I am using loaded modules of gcc/10.2 and cuda/11.1
Is there anything I missed, or any suggestion would be great.
Thanks

Hello
Can you print the output of the diagnostics script in moose/scripts ?
This will likely be a case of inconsistent MPI between various phases of installation
Guillaume
by different phases of installation you mean compilation and execution ?

which page did you follow for installation?
There's also different phases of installation, depending on which page you followed

node.title: Binary KKS model + tensor mechanics + Discrete Nucleation
node.bodyText:
Hello!
I am in the process of constructing a KKS model for studying the evolution of a two-phase (⍺/δ) binary system (H-Zr). The tensor mechanics module is used to account for the eigenstrain of precipitate during formation and their contribution to the global free energy.
Questions:
I am now trying to implement nucleation by using the Discrete Nucleation System. I track the H concentration of the δ-precipitate and ⍺-matrix (i.e., c = c_δ + c_⍺) in this KKS model. But I am not quite sure what I should do for the "DiscreteNucleation" material and the "op_names" input: Should it be 'c_δ c_⍺' or just 'c'?  Do both the δ-precipitate and the ⍺-matrix have a Discrete Nucleation material? like fn_δ= p(c_δ-c_δ^eq)^2 and  fn_⍺= p(c_⍺-c_⍺^eq)^2 ?
Thank you!
-Cloris

node.title: Install in a workstation
node.bodyText:
Hello, although i install many times in my pc, i meet a problem in a offline workstation. I did the flowing steps.

creat a same with pc username.
install in pc(online)
copy the mambaconfig3 files into the workstation
make the test
there is no problem in make, but when i test it fail.

Is due to my gcc is too old?
What's your version of gcc?
oh copying over the folder wont work

please follow these instructions instead
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/getting_started/installation/offline_installation.html

oh copying over the folder wont work

the copy is work, i solve this problem because my GNULIBC is 2.17, but moose need is at least 2.22. i update and it works

node.title: A general question about the optimal number of processors and threads
node.bodyText:
Hello everyone,
I am solving a 2D model. The 2D mesh is 30*25 with 5 levels of refinement. My first question is how can I get the number of elements and DOFs with the refined mesh? I am asking this because I think the numbers I got at the output are based on unrefined mesh.
I also want to know how can I speed up the simulation process. Herein I run the simulation with 94 CPUs, but it is not as fast as I wanted it to be. Moreover, my advisor has a COMSOL model of this simulation which took it like 2 hours to produce results, but mine took me like 15 hours. Based on this and MOOSE parallelism framework, I think there should be a way that I can increase the speed of my simulation! Especially I want to do it also in 3D which is much more time-consuming, so finding a way to speed up the 2D model is essential for me. I would appreciate suggestions by MOOSE experts in this manner. I also attached some information about my model.
Thanks,
Ali
MOOSE Version:           git commit cb1ac8f on 2023-04-10
LibMesh Version:         80494219d2293e467392189814d30330c4f87a25
PETSc Version:           3.16.6
SLEPc Version:           3.16.2
Current Time:            Sat Apr 22 11:12:53 2023
Executable Timestamp:    Sat Apr 22 10:44:09 2023

Parallelism:
  Num Processors:          94
  Num Threads:             1

Mesh: 
  Parallel Type:           replicated
  Mesh Dimension:          2
  Spatial Dimension:       2
  Nodes:                   
    Total:                 806
    Local:                 15
    Min/Max/Avg:           0/17/8
  Elems:                   
    Total:                 750
    Local:                 8
    Min/Max/Avg:           7/8/7
  Num Subdomains:          1
  Num Partitions:          94
  Partitioner:             metis

Nonlinear System:
  Num DOFs:                4030
  Num Local DOFs:          75
  Variables:               { "vel_x" "vel_y" "p" "c" "w" } 
  Finite Element Types:    "LAGRANGE" 
  Approximation Orders:    "FIRST" 

Auxiliary System:
  Num DOFs:                5362
  Num Local DOFs:          70
  Variables:               { "x_coor" "y_coor" } { "jump" "error" "F" "mu" "rho" } 
  Finite Element Types:    "LAGRANGE" "MONOMIAL" 
  Approximation Orders:    "FIRST" "CONSTANT" 

Execution Information:
  Executioner:             Transient
  TimeStepper:             ConstantDT
  TimeIntegrator:          ImplicitEuler
  Solver Mode:             NEWTON
  PETSc Preconditioner:    asm 
  MOOSE Preconditioner:    SMP

This doesn’t look refined 5 times
how are you refining?

[Adaptivity]
  initial_steps = 5
  steps = 1
  marker = error
  [Indicators]
    [jump]
      type = GradientJumpIndicator
      variable = c
    []
  []
  [Markers]
    [error]
      type = ErrorFractionMarker
      coarsen = 0.95
      refine = 0.9
      indicator = jump
    []
  []
  max_h_level = 5
[]

Ok this looks fine. It s just not uniform refinement which would have been reported correctly in the summary.
So there is a NumElems Postprocessor you can use to report on the number of elements

[Adaptivity]
  initial_steps = 5
  steps = 1
  marker = error
  [Indicators]
    [jump]
      type = GradientJumpIndicator
      variable = c
    []
  []
  [Markers]
    [error]
      type = ErrorFractionMarker
      coarsen = 0.95
      refine = 0.9
      indicator = jump
    []
  []
  max_h_level = 5
[]



Can you tell me for this kind of mesh which is extremely fine in 1 region, and it is coarse elsewhere, what kind of partitioner is useful?
Thanks,
Ali

metis will do fine.
this mesh is stored in an exodus file now right?
Use the filemeshgenerator to read it, then the partitioner should act on it when running in parallel
To look at the action of the partitioner, see the show_domain option in the Debug block
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/actions/SetupDebugAction.html

I am generating the mesh with "GeneratedMeshGenerator" and use "GradientJumpIndicator" for mesh adaptivity (I am not using and saving any exodus file for mesh). Besides it is a transient problem and mesh will be changed in each time step. So there is a way that I can generate the mesh and store it and then read it in each time step?
I also tried show_domain in the debug, nothing appeared there and I didn't see it in the documentation either!
it adds the partitioning to the exodus output so you can look at it
I know it s not ideal to use a FileMeshGenerator. i d like you to try loading the refined mesh so we can see what the impact of re-partitioning would be on performance
Ok, so can you tell me what should I add to save the mesh in exodus format and then use "FileMeshGenerator" to read it?

[Outputs]
  exodus = true
[]

in the first simulation
then in the second use this
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/meshgenerators/FileMeshGenerator.html
also it s show_process_domains I think for the boolean in Debug. Please check the parameters

With regards to performance, one thing we need here is a step of repartitioning as the initial partitioning is not great or adapted to the non-uniform refinement
  Nodes:                   
    Total:                 806
    Local:                 15
    Min/Max/Avg:           0/17/8

I dont know how, but one domain seems to own 0 nodes!
To try this, I would generate the mesh in a simulation, then load it using a FileMeshGenerator. This will ensure better partitioning

I do not know how to implement this in my input file. Is there any example for mesh generation in simulation and loading it with FileMesh Generator? I am also wondering about the partitioner. I think the default one is metis as I did not define anything for that in my mesh. Could it affect the performance? I also attached all of the parts related to the mesh in my input file!
[Mesh]
[gen]
  type = GeneratedMeshGenerator
  dim = 2
  nx = 25
  ny = 30
  nz = 0
  xmin = 0
  ymin = 0
  zmin = 0
  xmax = 0.5
  ymax = 0.6
  zmax = 0
  elem_type = QUAD4
[]
[]

[Adaptivity]
  initial_steps = 5
  steps = 1
  marker = error
  [Indicators]
    [jump]
      type = GradientJumpIndicator
      variable = c
    []
  []
  [Markers]
    [error]
      type = ErrorFractionMarker
      coarsen = 0.95
      refine = 0.9
      indicator = jump
    []
  []
  max_h_level = 5
[]

Another major potential slowdown is insufficient work on each processor. How many elements do you have in total now?
We operate better with 20k element per process
DOF is around 120,000. It means that number of CPUs should be 6. But increasing number of CPUs speed up the simulation in my problem!

ok but 90 is well beyond our "good scaling" expectation.
20k dofs/processor is not a uniform rule. you should try several numbers of processes, see what works best

All right. Now I tried to simulate my model in 3d, having 1 cpu per 20,000 DOFs, this would lead to 50 CPUs in my problem, so I run on 84. But just 1 time step took me like 2 hours! I think something is wrong here and I can't figure it out.

Num Local DOFs:          2994
this is still concerning with regards to partitioning
The solve method might be a little simplistic still, asm-lu
You may want to write a field split.
there's a good example here
https://github.com/idaholab/moose/blob/next/modules/navier_stokes/test/tests/finite_volume/ins/channel-flow/2d-rc-no-slip.i
I think that number for local DOFs is incorrect, since from the first step mesh adaptivity exists, which makes that number underestimated!
How much changing the time integrator could change the performance? Maybe it is the implicit scheme that makes it too long. I am also running my 2D model with euler explicit scheme.

well there's a trade off. It s likely the implicit scheme is letting you take longer time steps than the explicit one.
We indeed do support explicit schemes if you want to use that
no it should be working. What s the trouble?

My 2D model takes like 2 days to run. It produces pretty good results, but my advisor has a comsol model for my problem that took like 3 hours with a finer mesh.
My 3D MOOSE model takes like 1 day just for 10 time steps with a course grid and around 1e6 DOFs.

If you want COMSOL-like performance you ll need to take a deep dive into the numerics.
You need to be using an optimized numerical scheme, with the right preconditioning and sometimes segregation between variables and so on.
Just throwing asm at all the variables alltogether is not a fast way to solve a problem.
Please explore the field split preconditioning option at least, though I could see a segregated scheme make sense here between the fluid and c-w

Thank you for the helpful suggestions!
I am working on field split preconditioning to get faster results. Is segregated solver supported in MOOSE?

We support multiple non linear system, and we will roll out a segregated solver for Navier Stokes in the coming month.
For an easy user interface from the input file, probably next year. For now, will have to be done on the C++ side for the general case

Is this on a cluster or on your local machine?
How many MPI ranks?
It is on cluster with 84 processors and 1.5e6 DOF. How can I get the number for MPI ranks?

ok please run your job then use this script
https://github.com/idaholab/moose/blob/next/framework/scripts/find_hung_process.py
it will tell us which process is getting stuck and where

This is what I got.
~/projects/moose/framework/scripts/find_hung_process.py -s 5 -f 1886620 ~/projects/moose/3d2/combined-opt 
Unique Stack Traces

~/projects/moose/framework/scripts/find_hung_process.py -s 10 -f 1886620 ~/projects/moose/3d2/combined-opt 
Unique Stack Traces

node.title: How to use one block's information and put in a different block's boundary condition with existing kernels?
node.bodyText: For a battery, there will be an anode, cathode and electrolyte separately represented as blocks. Say block 1 for anode, 2 for electrolyte and 3 for cathode. Each block will have their diffusion ODEs for evolution of their respective ionic concentrations say c_a, c_e and c_c for blocks 1, 2 and 3 respectively. The connection between the blocks are only through the boundary conditions where block 1 is connected to block 2 via some current boundary condition in which c_e (block 2 variable) extreme cell value appears. The same is for the other blocks. Is it possible to use some existing kernels to perform this without coding anything.

Hello
I dont think we have a boundary condition that depends directly on the extreme value of a variable over one block.
You could get a prototype going where this extreme gets computed using an ExtremeValuePostprocessor, then use this in a ParsedMaterial or a ParsedAux (the Jacobian will be imperfect, but this is just a first draft).
You can then use the material property or auxiliary variable defined to help build this boundary condition
The boundary condition may or may not already exist in the framework, we would need to know the expression to determine that.

Each block will have their diffusion ODEs for evolution of their respective ionic concentrations say c_a, c_e and c_c for blocks 1, 2 and 3 respectively

You mean PDE right? Or is steady state 1D diffusion?
Guillaume

The actual problem is a PDE which I have broken down into simpler problems. I have figured out how to handle the other parts but am

stuck with how to add the robin bc. To explain this part of the problem, I have attached a file where there are two subdomains with its different variables. These variables are interconnected by boundary conditions at interface. Can you please guide me how to take it further?

The robin BC can be implemented as an interface kernel here.
They look fairly like a BC but they are meant to couple touching subdomains

To solve this problem. I am first trying to run the examples provided. In many of the cases I find a missing kernel. Where can I find the application for it? For example, this is an example I was trying to run, but Coefparamdiffusion is an unregistered object.
eg.txt
How can I go about?

is this this one?
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/kernels/CoefDiffusion.html
It is in this folder test/tests/interfacekernels/2d_interface/coupled_value_coupled_flux.i

that's a test object then.
If you cant use the one I linked to, you can use the test object only with the test executable and also passing --allow-test-objects on the command line
I could solve. Thanks for helping out!

Hi,
There is no kernel named RobinBC. Were you saying about the BC or the kernel? To implement this boundary condition, which interface kernel can I use?

This boundary condition is a BC not a kernel.
You should use the BC system
You can have a look at the code in the electromagnetics module for this BC
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/docs/PRs/24293/site/source/bcs/EMRobinBC.html
EMRbinBC seems to work for single variable. Am I missing something? My system has total 4 variables and 3 variables in the Robin BC. Can I still use this, or I have to make a custom BC?
You have to make a custom one. We dont have something that will just do f(something) or g(something) for the BC like you have in your equation. There is no ParsedBC (currently)
Okay. Thankyou! I will try this out

node.title: issue with building the test after update
node.bodyText:
Hi, I have an m1 macbook air and had a working moose. But recently when I created new application, running the first test gave me segmentation error. So, I updated moose and now I cannot even make the tests in the moose directory to test if moose works right. this is the error I get when I try to make in the /projects/moose/test/ directory:
I tried installing packaging (pip install packaging and python -m ensurepip --upgrade) but it already has the packaging.
I would appreciate it if you could help me out. Thanks.
I also tried the steps in https://mooseframework.inl.gov/help/troubleshooting.html#buildissues
and got the mentioned outputs. but this error still is:
Traceback (most recent call last):
File "/Users/kiankhaksar/projects/moose/framework/scripts/get_repo_revision.py", line 19, in 
from packaging import version
ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'packaging'
Checking if header needs updating: /Users/kiankhaksar/projects/moose/framework/include/base/MooseRevision.h...
Failed to generate MooseRevision.h
make: *** [/Users/kiankhaksar/projects/moose/framework/moose.mk:347: /Users/kiankhaksar/projects/moose/framework/include/base/MooseRevision.h] Error 1

Hello
Are you not using mamba?
Why are you using pip?
Guillaume

Hi,
Thanks for the reply.
Yes, I am using mamba. I searched for possible solutions. they suggested insalling packaging this way. How may I resolve the issue?
Thanks.
I just tried (mamba install packaging). But I am still getting the same thing.

I'm worried there's different python being found.
What does which python return ?

This is the output:
/Users/kiankhaksar/mambaforge3/envs/moose/bin/python
in fact what does the diagnostics script in moose/scripts return?

This is the output: /Users/kiankhaksar/mambaforge3/envs/moose/bin/python

looks good

I run the diagnostics.sh file in the terminal and this is the output:

PATH=/opt/homebrew/bin this is likely the problem
Let s shuffle this up, get conda before homebrew
export PATH="/Users/kiankhaksar/mambaforge3/envs/moose/bin:/Users/kiankhaksar/mambaforge3/condabin:$PATH"

It started to build! and the tests are being OK'ed! still running!
Thank you very much. I really appreciate it.
So, using this command, I added the the paths to moose/bin and mambaforge3/condabin before the path to homebrew? since the program was accessing the python of homebrew before the python of moose? I'm guessing!
Is there a way of permanently changing the PATH ?
Thank you for your help.

Yes homebrew was (is) briniging in another python
You can add this command to your .bash_profile
